captions.text: (sniff) agh, I love the smell of CGI in the morning

We are so thankful the sky-people
will no longer destroy our land.
I hate to ask now but...
why were they knocking over trees in the first place?

What?!? Jake.. whatever happened to
becoming one of them and..

earning their trust so you can explain
what we needed?
Hgm, well I was I was going to but I sort of umm,
Look, lets just bug out and call it even, ok?
What are we even talking about this for?

I say we take off and nuke the entire site
from orbit.
it's the only way to be sure

comments.author: Pedro Purcino

comments.text:
+Pedro Purcino yes, and i fully agree with your opinion entirely. it's 
easier to clean up our own planet than steal resources from other planets.

but i just wanted to make the comparison. there IS no "clean" bomb in 
existence that could match the power needed to do that kind of damage. at 
least, not without expeditious amounts of that explosive. it has to do with 
were the energy comes from.

TNT and other "clean" explosives get their energy from a chemical reaction. 
in terms of einstein's equation E=mc^2, it is one of the most inefficient 
explosions known to man. the mass that gets converted to energy is so 
little, you wouldnt even be able to measure its efficiency in percent.

nukes on the other hand get their energy from nuclear bonds, using either 
fission or fusion to convert matter into energy. in fission, large atoms 
like plutonium or uranium are broken down into smaller atoms. in fusion, 
small atoms like tritium (a hydrogen isotope) are combined to make larger 
atoms.

since these reactions are atomic scale and have to deal with forces like 
the strong force, far more of the mass is converted to energy, so even less 
mass is needed for the same explosive potential.

even nukes are only 0.3% efficient according to E=mc^2. a truly 100% 
efficient reaction would mean only 1 kg (2.2 pounds) of material would 
produce an explosion equivalent to 21 megatons of TNT.

sorry, i know this is probably coming off as gibberish, but i just find it 
a fascinating subject. the truth is, there arent many "clean" ways to go 
about producing the explosive power you need efficiently. no chemical 
reaction can match the efficiency of a nuclear reaction. other alternatives 
i can think of would still require large amounts of mass, and mass simply 
doesnt like being transported.

anyway, i'd recommend looking at those pictures i posted anyway. even if 
you dont really have an interest in the subject, it's a real eye opener to 
the kind of destruction man kind is capable of.
comments.author: justme man

comments.text:
+justme man i dont have expert knowledge about explosives, i just used this 
kind of explosive as one tipe that would not leave radioactive waste, but 
we can agree they could use a "clean" bomb to attack form outside the 
atmosphere, and the humans would win.

but my real point here is: if the humans can cross the galaxy, why not 
learn how to live without destroying your own planet? sounds logical and 
really productive to me.
comments.author: Pedro Purcino

comments.text:
+Pedro Purcino well im not gonna bother reading that entire flame war.

but i will bother answering your first response:

nukes are measured in kilotons and megatons, as in how many thousands or 
millions of tons of TNT are equivalent to the explosion.

let's put things into perspective:

the bomb dropped on hiroshima was 15 kilotons of explosive power. meaning 
15 THOUSAND tons of TNT, or 15 MILLION KILOGRAMS of TNT... 

here's a picture of perspective:

http://i387.photobucket.com/albums/oo320/Nmenth/TNT4.jpg

hiroshima, i might remind you, was one of the smallest nuclear detonations 
in recorded history. if you wanted to carpet bomb a planet, it would not be 
suitable. what WOULD be suitable would be the Tsar bomb.

the Tsar bomb was the largest single nuclear detonation. it had an 
explosive force of 50 MEGAtons. that's 50 MILLION tons of TNT, or 50 
BILLION kg of TNT.

here's more pictures to give you a better sense of scale:

http://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-9d50d939638c4b5fa1881876ee494f3d?convert_to_webp=true

this is the power of hiroshima's explosion as compared to that of the Tsar 
bomb.

http://www.tsarbomba.org/images/Comparative_nuclear_fireball_sizes.png

this is the comparison of the Tsar bombs blast radius compared to that of 
other nukes. nagasaki is the smallest one in the picture. hiroshima's blast 
radius was too small to be depicted accurately.

http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--97Wdg1Ud--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/17k71xh2xk2zdjpg.jpg

this is a photo that draws out each individual kiloton of TNT to give you 
an idea of scale.

http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--aVCCzCFN--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/17k71xqy4i81kjpg.jpg

the tsar bomb's explosive potential was so great, it had to be put into an 
image separate from that of the others in this comparison.

and finally, we have the raw tonnage of TNT required visualized:

http://s387.photobucket.com/user/Nmenth/media/TNT5.jpg.html

even further, the tsar bomb that was actually detonated was a watered down 
version that used a lead lining instead of the production version's 
depleted uranium lining. a FULL tsar bomb would have had the explosive 
potential of 100 megatons (or, 100 million tons, or 100 BILLION kgs, or 220 
BILLION pounds of TNT). so, go back, look through those images, and double 
everything you just saw for the tsar bomb in comparison to everything else.

even further, you would need many tsar bombs to hit every major population 
area on pandora. let's say, 30, just for good measure. so in addition to 
the doubling you just did, go back and multiply all those comparisons by 
30, to get the full scope of what a real world orbital bombardment would 
require... to put that into perspective, that is 3000 megatons, or 3 
GIGAtons of TNT. that's 3 BILLION tons of TNT, or, 3 TRILLION kgs of TNT, 
or 6.6 TRILLION pounds of TNT.

... yeah, i dont think conventional explosives are the way to go in any 
orbital bombardment. good luck getting even a measurable fraction of that 
6.6 trillion pounds of TNT into orbit, let alone all the way to pandora... 
and on what? a ship that masses far less than that. in order to even 
TRANSPORT 6.6 trillion pounds of TNT, you need a ship that masses far more 
than that... yeah, good luck with that. so trust me when i say an orbital 
bombardment with conventional explosives is utterly pointless or utterly 
impossible.

people always make the mistake of underestimating the power of nuclear 
weapons. conventional explosives dont even compare, and never will.

comments.author: golden eyeRA

comments.text:
+golden eyeRA Everyone cares about punctuation when its the only thing that 
might make it possible for me to understand wtf you're trying to say.

Punctuation and paragraphs. They exist for a reason, largely to make 
reading easy. If you care enough to post something you should care if 
people can actually understand it.

Besides, you're using capitals. Why use capitals at the start of a sentence 
when you won't use periods?

comments.text:
+golden eyeRA And working for the company, studying and researching on the 
company's dime.

Its not the wild west with wagons of pilgrims rolling into town, every 
person on that planet is there on behalf of the project which will 
inevitably disenfranchise the Navi from their own home.

Doesn't matter who anybody is, you roll into town with the bandits you're 
gonna get treated about as well as the bandits. However it was shown that 
some of the scientists were given some latitude, but still barely tolerated 
as they knew what they represented.
